rounds.observation:
You are Player 0 in the Negotiation Game.
You have some resources, and your task is to trade such that the total value of your resources increases.
The resources and associated values you currently have are:
	+ [Wheat]   Qty: 12   Value: 6
	+ [Wood]    Qty: 14   Value: 10
	+ [Sheep]   Qty: 9    Value: 13
	+ [Brick]   Qty: 8    Value: 23
	+ [Ore]     Qty: 24   Value: 33
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.
Use the following special tokens for actions:
  - '[Offer: 3 Sheep, 2 Ore -> 5 Brick, 2 Sheep]': [Offer: Offered Resources -> Requested Resources]
  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.
  - '[Deny]': To deny an incoming offer (default).
The game lasts for 10 turns in total.

	+ [Ore]     Qty: 18   Value: 34
At each turn, you can talk to your opponent and make a trade offer.

  - '[Accept]': To accept an incoming offer.

The game lasts for 10 turns in total.
 Player 0 made the following offer to Player 1: Offered items: 10 Wheat, 10 Wood -> Requested items: 5 Brick, 5 Ore
rounds.response:
Let me quickly value all the resources involved.

Their offer in my eyes  
+10 Wheat = 10 × 5 = 50  
+10 Wood  = 10 × 9 = 90  
Total I would gain = 140

What they ask from me  
−5 Brick = 5 × 23 = −115  
−5 Ore   = 5 × 34 = −170  
Total I would lose = −285

Net change for me = 140 − 285 = −145  
That is a huge drop in value, so the deal is very bad.

[Deny]

rounds.response:
Let me judge the incoming offer first.

Current holdings:
Wheat 21 (5) = 105
Wood 12 (9) = 108
Sheep 22 (14) = 308
Brick 22 (23) = 506
Ore 18 (34) = 612
Total current value = 1 639

Offer on the table  
GIVE: 5 Brick · 5 Ore  
Value you would give away: 5·23 + 5·34 = 115 + 170 = 285

GET: 10 Wheat · 10 Wood  
Value you would receive: 10·5 + 10·9 = 50 + 90 = 140

Gain = 140 – 285 = –145 → strongly negative.

Action on Player 0’s offer:
[Deny]

Now, since the prior mutual rejection means the turn ends without an accepted trade, I must decide whether
to make a fresh offer.  After the rejection both sides still hold the original quantities.

A balanced favorable deal (values ±0 for P1):

I value Sheep most strongly per-unit (14) and Brick second (23), and I’m content with my 21 Wheat.
I could trade surplus Sheep for more Ore (34), since Ore edges my value scale.

Proposed deal:
I give 4 Sheep (4·14 = 56 worth)  
I receive      2 Ore     (2·34 = 68 worth)  
Net gain for me = +12

For Player 0 the deal depends on their private valuations which I cannot see, but the raw same-scaled numbers make it only slightly unfavorable for them (56 vs 68) – well within negotiable range.

Making the new offer:
[Offer: 4 Sheep -> 2 Ore]

rounds.response:
I need to carefully analyze the proposed trades and decide what would benefit me most.

Looking at the current values:
- Wheat: 5
- Wood: 9
- Sheep: 14
- Brick: 23
- Ore: 34

The first offer I received: 10 Wheat + 10 Wood for 5 Brick + 5 Ore
- Value offered: (10×5) + (10×9) = 50 + 90 = 140
- Value requested: (5×23) + (5×34) = 115 + 170 = 285
This trade would've cost me 285 value for only 140 value - clearly bad for me.

My last offer: 4 Sheep for 2 Ore
- Value offered: 4×14 = 56
- Value requested: 2×34 = 68
This was slightly favorable for me (68-56 = 12 value gain), but was rejected.

I should now propose a more balanced trade that benefits me more significantly. Based on my analysis, I have:
- Lots of Brick (22 qty, 23 value) and Ore (18 qty, 34 value) which are high-value
- Large quantities of lower-value resources like Wheat (21 qty, 5 value) and Sheep (22 qty, 14 value)

[Offer: 8 Wheat, 8 Sheep -> 6 Brick, 2 Ore]

rounds.response:
It's now the start of turn 5.

Current value check  
- My value at the beginning of the game was  
  21·5 + 12·9 + 22·14 + 22·23 + 18·34 = 1747

Current stock (I did not accept any trade ⇒ quantities unchanged).  
Task: *increase* my total value while still offering something that looks reasonable to Player 0.

Good deals that would clearly help me
- Off-load some of the bulky, low-value Wheat (5 pts) or Wood (9 pts).  
- Acquire extra Ore (34 pts) or at least Brick (23 pts).  
- I don’t want to give away too much Sheep (14 pts) because it is the best of my three “RGB” goods.

New proposal (slightly better ratio for him than last time so it might land):

[Offer: 6 Wheat, 6 Sheep -> 5 Brick, 3 Ore]

Value analysis for me  
I give 6·5 + 6·14 = 19×6 = 114 value  
I get 5·23 + 3·34 = 115 + 102 = 217 value  
Net gain = 217 - 114 = 103 pts

Ratio seams reasonable (19 of my value vs 23 of his on quick visual), so he may be tempted.

Next action:
[Offer: 6 Wheat, 6 Sheep -> 5 Brick, 3 Ore]

rounds.response:
I'm going to look down my list of current resources and values:

- Wheat 21 @5  
- Wood 12 @9  
- Sheep 22 @14  
- Brick 22 @23  
- Ore 18 @34  

Total value I control: 2 103.

I’ve already been rejected when I asked for just 2 Ore for 4 Sheep, and when I sweetened the wheat-to-sheep ratio nothing worked. That tells me Player 0 has no spare Ore or Brick and/or refuses to break their set at all, no matter how generous the rate.

My biggest single upside would be to turn my surplus Wheat and Sheep (low-value to me) into Ore and possibly Brick. Since my last Wheat+Sheep package (6 Wheat + 6 Sheep → 5 Brick + 3 Ore = 199 value acquired vs 244 value given: a 45-value loss to me already) was flatly rejected, doubling down by offering even more value isn’t attractive.

Likewise, giving up any Brik or Ore would be expensive (23 and 34 value each), so I don’t want to part with those unless the return is spectacular.

Observation: Player 0 refuses anything that delivers valuable resources (Brick, Ore) to me. They’ll sacrifice lower-value cards but only if they get absolutely lopsided “sell-the-farm” rates, which hurt me more than help.

Therefore I cannot, in the current trade window, increase my total value without dramatically over-paying, an action that is net-loss to me.

Since making any further offers would simply lower my expected value, I will decline to offer a trade this round and await Player 0’s move.

[Deny]
